Query1.snippet: Apr 7, 2019 ... From 'The Beast' to a golf cart, all Secret Service members have extensive training.

content.content:
Protecting the president of the United States involves far more than being willing to step into the path of gunfire.
As part of their extensive training — ranging from firearms to first aid — all of the several thousand Secret Service agents and officers also have to learn how to drive.
The training, which takes place at a 550-meter (546-yard) track in the state of Maryland, goes way beyond the fundamentals of defensive driving. Among the techniques is the J-turn, in which the driver spins a reversing vehicle 180 degrees and quickly continues, facing forward, with brisk acceleration.
**WATCH: 'Beast,' Bus, Motorcycles — Secret Service Has to Drive it All**
​**Protective driving**
For the Secret Service, this is part of “protective driving,” which has one goal: “Safely get the protectee out of the area — the ‘kill zone’ — and to move them to a safe location as quickly and expeditiously as possible,” according to Thomas Murach, Secret Service assistant to the special agent-in-charge.
Even after the completion of that five-day training, Secret Service personnel are not ready to get behind the wheel of the 9,000-kilogram (9.9-ton) armored presidential stretch limousine known as Cadillac One, or The Beast.
Anyone driving the president or vice president must have passed a separate, advanced five-day training known as the Protective Operations Driving Course, which has about a 60 percent pass rate.

I don't own a firearm or even a decent set of running shoes. (If you see me running, something behind me is on fire.) I am the polar opposite of a survivalist: In the event of a nuclear war, my goal is to die in the initial attack. Barring that, I'll be the guy on the roof with a sign that says, "Unarmed; house full of money, food, and tools."
So it is rather unfortunate that I waited until after my plane tickets were booked to read the message in detail and realizeexactlywhat I was in for, which is to learn how to avoid being captured by bad guys—and how to escape if it happens anyway.
Neither the class nor the teacher was what I expected. I envisioned Hanson as a bulky, shouty, camo-clad man who would rip off his wrap-around sunglasses and fix me with a glare that dismissed me as worthless and weak. Instead, he turned out to be a tidy, well-spoken sort with a physique that was muscular but lean, and thin enough that I feared he'd disappear if he turned sideways. Hanson runs his own security and executive protection business, and while he is not allowed to specifically link them, his course is based on CIA techniques he passed on to spies he recruited—or rather would have done had he actually recruited spies, which of course he did not do and the CIA does not do, or so I have been assured by the stern-looking men in suits who just showed up at my doorstep.
The people who take the class are not the militia-wannabe types I envisioned, either. Instead, Hanson's workshops attract folks with well-founded concerns about carjacking or kidnapping-for-ransom, including high-profile executives and high-net-worth individuals (which means me and my fellowMotorTrendstaffers are all safe). For them, getting robbed or snatched is a real concern, and they want to learn how to get away—preferably by car—from a bad situation and how to escape from a worse one.

content.content:
Being a U.S. Secret Service agent is a demanding and challenging job that requires a high level of physical and mental fitness, as well as specialized training in law enforcement and security. Secret Service agents are responsible for protecting the President, Vice President, their families, and other high-ranking government officials, as well as investigating financial crimes and counterfeiting.
The training process for Secret Service agents is rigorous and can take several months to complete. The initial training program, which takes place at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center (FLETC) in Glynco, Georgia, lasts approximately 7 months. During this time, trainees receive intensive instruction in criminal law, firearms training, physical fitness, and defensive tactics.
After completing the initial training program, new agents go through a period of on-the-job training, which can last up to 18 months. During this time, they work alongside experienced agents and receive further training in specialized areas such as protective intelligence, protective operations, and investigative techniques.
In addition to initial training, Secret Service agents are required to complete ongoing training throughout their careers to maintain their skills and stay up-to-date on the latest security and law enforcement techniques.
The job of a Secret Service agent can be demanding and stressful, but it can also be rewarding and fulfilling. Agents have the opportunity to work closely with high-level government officials and to play a crucial role in protecting the safety and security of the United States.
It's important to note that becoming a Secret Service agent is a highly competitive process, and not everyone who applies will be accepted into the training program. Applicants must meet strict eligibility requirements, including having a clean criminal record, passing a rigorous physical fitness test, and demonstrating a commitment to public service.
